001package squidpony.squidmath;
002
003/**
004 * A group of similar methods for getting hashes of points based on int coordinates in 2, 3, 4, or 6 dimensions and
005 * an int for state; the code is similar to {@link HastyPointHash} but will be much faster on GWT. This
006 * implementation has high enough quality to be useful as a source of random numbers based on positions, but would
007 * likely not be a good option in a hash table (or at least not as good as the tailored implementation of
008 * {@link Coord#hashCode()}; it is still better than {@link java.util.Objects#hash(Object...)}). Even on a desktop
009 * JVM, this class is faster than {@link PointHash} or {@link HastyPointHash}. The technique used here
010 * owes credit to Pelle Evensen for finding the significant quality increase from using multiple bitwise rotations XORed
011 * together, and Martin Roberts for discovering the connection between higher dimensional ranks and the appropriate
012 * numbers to gain similar qualities to adding the golden ratio mod 1 in 1D, using what had already been named
013 * "harmonious numbers." The only case where this can return different results on GWT than on a desktop or mobile
014 * JVM is when the inputs are GWT-specific out-of-range JS Numbers appearing to be ints, and that's a problem with
015 * the input rather than the algorithm.
016 * <br>
017 * Getting the bottom 24 bits of {@link #hashAll(int, int, int)}, dividing to get a float from 0 to 1, and graphing
018 * it produces <a href="https://i.imgur.com/vYWzVAR.png">this white-noise-like image</a>. The frequency magnitude of
019 * that image is <a href="https://i.imgur.com/6N39FPQ.png">this diagram</a>, which looks almost exactly like
020 * <a href="https://i.imgur.com/RSdUnSY.png">a diagram of the frequency magnitude of white noise</a>. This shows
021 * there are effectively no significant structural artifacts in the noise when interpreted as a float.
022 */
023public final class IntPointHash extends IPointHash.IntImpl {
024
025    public static final IntPointHash INSTANCE = new IntPointHash();
026    @Override
027    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int state) {
028        return hashAll(x, y, state);
029    }
030
031    @Override
032    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int state) {
033        return hashAll(x, y, z, state);
034    }
035
036    @Override
037    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int state) {
038        return hashAll(x, y, z, w, state);
039    }
040
041    @Override
042    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int state) {
043        return hashAll(x, y, z, w, u, state);
044    }
045
046    @Override
047    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int state) {
048        return hashAll(x, y, z, w, u, v, state);
049    }
050
051    /**
052     * A 32-bit point hash that smashes x and y into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
053     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
054     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
055     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
056     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
057     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
058     * @param x x position, as an int
059     * @param y y position, as an int
060     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
061     * @return 32-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state s
062     */
063    public static int hashAll(int x, int y, int s) {
064        s ^= x * 0x1827F5 ^ y * 0x123C21;
065        return (s = (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493) ^ s >>> 11;
066    }
067    /**
068     * A 32-bit point hash that smashes x, y, and z into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
069     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
070     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
071     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
072     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
073     flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
074     * @param x x position, as an int
075     * @param y y position, as an int
076     * @param z z position, as an int
077     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
078     * @return 32-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state s
079     */
080    public static int hashAll(int x, int y, int z, int s) {
081        s ^= x * 0x1A36A9 ^ y * 0x157931 ^ z * 0x119725;
082        return (s = (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493) ^ s >>> 11;
083    }
084
085    /**
086     * A 32-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, and w into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
087     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
088     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
089     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
090     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
091     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
092     * @param x x position, as an int
093     * @param y y position, as an int
094     * @param z z position, as an int
095     * @param w w position, as an int
096     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
097     * @return 32-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state s
098     */
099    public static int hashAll(int x, int y, int z, int w, int s) {
100        s ^= x * 0x1B69E1 ^ y * 0x177C0B ^ z * 0x141E5D ^ w * 0x113C31;
101        return (s = (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493) ^ s >>> 11;
102    }
103
104    /**
105     * A 32-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, w, u, and v into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious
106     * numbers, then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash,
107     * especially for ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by
108     * Pelle Evensen's rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary
109     * hash used here has been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected
110     * specifically to target flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that
111     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
112     * @param x x position, as an int
113     * @param y y position, as an int
114     * @param z z position, as an int
115     * @param w w position, as an int
116     * @param u u position, as an int
117     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point 
118     * @return 32-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u point with the given state s
119     */
120    public static int hashAll(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int s) {
121        s ^= x * 0x1C3360 ^ y * 0x18DA3A ^ z * 0x15E6DA ^ w * 0x134D28 ^ u * 0x110280;
122        return (s = (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493) ^ s >>> 11;
123    }
124
125    /**
126     * A 32-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, w, u, and v into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious
127     * numbers, then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash,
128     * especially for ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by
129     * Pelle Evensen's rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary
130     * hash used here has been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected
131     * specifically to target flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that
132     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
133     * @param x x position, as an int
134     * @param y y position, as an int
135     * @param z z position, as an int
136     * @param w w position, as an int
137     * @param u u position, as an int
138     * @param v v position, as an int
139     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point 
140     * @return 32-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state s
141     */
142    public static int hashAll(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int s) {
143        s ^= x * 0x1CC1C5 ^ y * 0x19D7AF ^ z * 0x173935 ^ w * 0x14DEAF ^ u * 0x12C139 ^ v * 0x10DAA3;
144        return (s = (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493) ^ s >>> 11;
145    }
146
147    /**
148     * A 8-bit point hash that smashes x and y into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
149     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
150     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
151     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
152     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
153     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
154     * @param x x position, as an int
155     * @param y y position, as an int
156     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
157     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state s
158     */
159    public static int hash256(int x, int y, int s) {
160        s ^= x * 0x1827F5 ^ y * 0x123C21;
161        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 24;
162    }
163    /**
164     * A 8-bit point hash that smashes x, y, and z into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
165     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
166     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
167     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
168     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
169     flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
170     * @param x x position, as an int
171     * @param y y position, as an int
172     * @param z z position, as an int
173     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
174     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state s
175     */
176    public static int hash256(int x, int y, int z, int s) {
177        s ^= x * 0x1A36A9 ^ y * 0x157931 ^ z * 0x119725;
178        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 24;
179    }

181    /**
182     * A 8-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, and w into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
183     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
184     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
185     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
186     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
187     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.

189     * @param y y position, as an int

191     * @param w w position, as an int
192     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
193     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state s
194     */
195    public static int hash256(int x, int y, int z, int w, int s) {
196        s ^= x * 0x1B69E1 ^ y * 0x177C0B ^ z * 0x141E5D ^ w * 0x113C31;

198    }

200    /**
201     * A 8-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, w, u, and v into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious
202     * numbers, then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash,
203     * especially for ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by
204     * Pelle Evensen's rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary
205     * hash used here has been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected
206     * specifically to target flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that
207     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
208     * @param x x position, as an int
209     * @param y y position, as an int
210     * @param z z position, as an int
211     * @param w w position, as an int
212     * @param u u position, as an int
213     * @param v v position, as an int
214     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point 
215     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state s
216     */
217    public static int hash256(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int s) {
218        s ^= x * 0x1CC1C5 ^ y * 0x19D7AF ^ z * 0x173935 ^ w * 0x14DEAF ^ u * 0x12C139 ^ v * 0x10DAA3;
219        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 24;
220    }

222    /**
223     * A 6-bit point hash that smashes x and y into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
224     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
225     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
226     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
227     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
228     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
229     * @param x x position, as an int
230     * @param y y position, as an int
231     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
232     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state s
233     */
234    public static int hash64(int x, int y, int s) {
235        s ^= x * 0x1827F5 ^ y * 0x123C21;
236        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 26;
237    }
238    /**
239     * A 6-bit point hash that smashes x, y, and z into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
240     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
241     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
242     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
243     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
244     flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
245     * @param x x position, as an int
246     * @param y y position, as an int
247     * @param z z position, as an int
248     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
249     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state s
250     */
251    public static int hash64(int x, int y, int z, int s) {
252        s ^= x * 0x1A36A9 ^ y * 0x157931 ^ z * 0x119725;
253        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 26;
254    }

257     * A 6-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, and w into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
258     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
259     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
260     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
261     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
262     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
263     * @param x x position, as an int
264     * @param y y position, as an int
265     * @param z z position, as an int
266     * @param w w position, as an int
267     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
268     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state s
269     */
270    public static int hash64(int x, int y, int z, int w, int s) {
271        s ^= x * 0x1B69E1 ^ y * 0x177C0B ^ z * 0x141E5D ^ w * 0x113C31;
272        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 26;
273    }

275    /**
276     * A 6-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, w, u, and v into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious
277     * numbers, then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash,
278     * especially for ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by
279     * Pelle Evensen's rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary
280     * hash used here has been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected
281     * specifically to target flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that
282     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
283     * @param x x position, as an int
284     * @param y y position, as an int
285     * @param z z position, as an int
286     * @param w w position, as an int
287     * @param u u position, as an int
288     * @param v v position, as an int
289     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point 
290     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state s
291     */
292    public static int hash64(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int s) {
293        s ^= x * 0x1CC1C5 ^ y * 0x19D7AF ^ z * 0x173935 ^ w * 0x14DEAF ^ u * 0x12C139 ^ v * 0x10DAA3;
294        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 26;
295    }
296    /**
297     * A 5-bit point hash that smashes x and y into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
298     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
299     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
300     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
301     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
302     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
303     * @param x x position, as an int
304     * @param y y position, as an int
305     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
306     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state s
307     */
308    public static int hash32(int x, int y, int s) {
309        s ^= x * 0x1827F5 ^ y * 0x123C21;
310        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 27;
311    }
312    /**
313     * A 5-bit point hash that smashes x, y, and z into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
314     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
315     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
316     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
317     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
318     flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.

323     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state s
324     */

330    /**
331     * A 5-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, and w into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
332     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
333     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
334     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
335     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
336     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
337     * @param x x position, as an int
338     * @param y y position, as an int
339     * @param z z position, as an int
340     * @param w w position, as an int
341     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
342     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state s
343     */
344    public static int hash32(int x, int y, int z, int w, int s) {
345        s ^= x * 0x1B69E1 ^ y * 0x177C0B ^ z * 0x141E5D ^ w * 0x113C31;
346        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 27;
347    }

349    /**
350     * A 5-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, w, u, and v into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious
351     * numbers, then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash,
352     * especially for ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by
353     * Pelle Evensen's rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary
354     * hash used here has been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected
355     * specifically to target flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that
356     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
357     * @param x x position, as an int
358     * @param y y position, as an int
359     * @param z z position, as an int
360     * @param w w position, as an int
361     * @param u u position, as an int
362     * @param v v position, as an int
363     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point 
364     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state s
365     */
366    public static int hash32(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int s) {
367        s ^= x * 0x1CC1C5 ^ y * 0x19D7AF ^ z * 0x173935 ^ w * 0x14DEAF ^ u * 0x12C139 ^ v * 0x10DAA3;
368        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 27;
369    }
